elements.content: The hydrothermal treatment of uranyl nitrate and 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid with a variety of aliphatic amines (tetramethylammonium hydroxide, tetraethylammonium hydroxide, and diethyldimethylammonium hydroxide) and small quantities of hydrofluoric acid at 200 °C results in the crystallization of a series of layered uranyl diphosphonate compounds, [(CH3)4N][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)]·0.5H2O (Me 4 Ubbp), [(CH3CH2)4N]{(UO2)[C6H4(PO3H)(PO3H1.5)]2(H2O)} (Et 4 Ubbp), and [(CH3CH2)2N(CH3)2][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)] (Et 2 Me 2 Ubbp). All these new compounds have layered structures, but the structures of Me 4 Ubbp and Et 2 Me 2 Ubbp are similar in that they both contain UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids within dimers that are bridged by the phosphonate into a three-dimensional structure. The structure of Et 4 Ubbp contains a single crystallographically unique UO7 unit. The edge-sharing pentagonal bipyramids are linked into chains formulated as {(UO2)[C6H4(PO3H)(PO3H1.5)]2(H2O)}1−. The voids in these structures are filled with the organic templates so that the overall charge balance is maintained. Intense fluorescence was observed from these compounds at room temperature.

All these new compounds have layered structures, but the structures of Me  4  Ubbp and Et  2  Me  2  Ubbp are similar in that they both contain UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids within dimers that are bridged by the phosphonate into a three-dimensional structure. The voids in these structures are filled with the organic templates so that the overall charge balance is maintained. Intense fluorescence was observed from these compounds at room temperature.

elements.content: Three uranyl diphosphonates with layered/pillared structural motifs have been prepared under mild hydrothermal conditions via the reaction of uranyl nitrate and 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid with a variety of aliphatic amines and hydrofluoric acid. The voids in these structures are filled with the organic templates. They all contain the UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids. These compounds fluoresce at room temperature.

The voids in these structures are filled with the organic templates. They all contain the UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids. These compounds fluoresce at room temperature.

elements.content: Interest in the solid-state chemistry of uranyl phosphonates developed as a result of the rich coordination chemistry of uranium(VI). The uranyl cation, UO2 2+, favors coordination of four to six additional donor atoms along the equatorial plane yielding tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramids in almost boundless combinations. The structural chemistry of phosphonates is intriguing, displaying transformation from one-dimensional α- and β-uranyl phenylphosphonates to nanotubular γ-uranyl phenylphosphonate upon exposure to Na+ or Ca2+ cations in aqueous solution. When the pillared compound, [C12H10N2]{(UO2)3[C6H4(PO3)2]2}·H2O is subjected to reimmersion in water, the structure undergoes a substantial rearrangement and recrystallization from a three-dimensional network where the diphosphonate ligand bridges between a layered substructure to where the diphosphonate bridges between one-dimensional chains in [C12H10N2]{UO2[C6H4(PO3)2]}. The formation of extended sheet structures as a result of the linear ‘yl’ oxo atoms of the actinyl units can be tremendously influenced through the incorporation of structure-directing agents, such as organoammonium cations. Additionally, when Cs+ cations are used to template the structure a remarkable nanotubular compound results, Cs3.62H0.38{(UO2)4[C6H4(PO2OH)2]3[C6H4(PO3)2]F2}. Immersion of this compound in Ag+-containing aqueous solution resulted in a partial exchange of the Cs+ cations with Ag+. The solid-state chemistry community is reaching the point where a topological relationship can be developed in uranyl oxoanion compounds, and, more importantly, the rudiments of materials design are taking place resulting in solids with selective ion-exchange, ionic conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, magnetic ordering, nonlinear optical properties, and differential gas sorption.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Interest in the solid-state chemistry of uranyl phosphonates developed as a result of the rich coordination chemistry of uranium(VI). The uranyl cation, UO2 2+, favors coordination of four to six additional donor atoms along the equatorial plane yielding tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramids in almost boundless combinations. The structural chemistry of phosphonates is intriguing, displaying transformation from one-dimensional α- and β-uranyl phenylphosphonates to nanotubular γ-uranyl phenylphosphonate upon exposure to Na+ or Ca2+ cations in aqueous solution. When the pillared compound, [C12H10N2]{(UO2)3[C6H4(PO3)2]2}⋅H2O is subjected to reimmersion in water, the structure undergoes a substantial rearrangement and recrystallization from a three-dimensional network where the diphosphonate ligand bridges between a layered substructure to where the diphosphonate bridges between one-dimensional chains in [C12H10N2]{UO2[C6H4(PO3)2]}. The formation of extended sheet structures as a result of the linear ‘yl' oxo atoms of the actinyl units can be tremendously influenced through the incorporation of structure-directing agents, such as organoammonium cations. Additionally, when Cs+ cations are used to template the structure a remarkable nanotubular compound results, Cs3.62H0.38{(UO2)4[C6H4(PO2OH)2]3[C6H4(PO3)2]F2}. Immersion of this compound in Ag+-containing aqueous solution resulted in a partial exchange of the Cs+ cations with Ag+. The solid-state chemistry community is reaching the point where a topological relationship can be developed in uranyl oxoanion compounds, and, more importantly, the rudiments of materials design are taking place resulting in solids with selective ion-exchange, ionic conductivity, intercalation chemistry, photochemistry, magnetic ordering, nonlinear optical properties, and differential gas sorption.

elements.content: Until recently, the solid-state structural chemistry of actinide arylphosphonates has been underexplored despite their importance in nuclear waste management and separation processes. Framework uranyl phosphates have been shown to be promising ion exchangers for the radionuclides 137Cs and 90Sr. It has been demonstrated that N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA) in an organically templated uranium phosphate fluoride material can be replaced by alkaline earth metal cations.
elements.clean_text: Until recently, the solid-state structural chemistry of actinide arylphosphonates has been underexplored despite their importance in nuclear waste management and separation processes. Framework uranyl phosphates have been shown to be promising ion exchangers for the radionuclides 137Cs and 90Sr. It has been demonstrated that N,N,N',N'-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA) in an organically templated uranium phosphate fluoride material can be replaced by alkaline earth metal cations.

elements.content: In this hydrothermal synthesis, hydrofluoric acid has been used as a mineralizing agent. When a large amount of F− ions are present in the reactions, they can be incorporated into the product to yield new and varied structure types, with fluoride acting as a ligand. It has been previously shown that rigid diphosphonates with phenyl spacers can be used in combination with uranyl cations and organic templates to construct pillared structures that fluoresce at room temperature. The voids in these structures are filled with protonated aromatic amines, which behave as templates and/or structure directing agents. As an expansion of this work, we have probed how aliphatic amines may influence either electronically and/or sterically the formation of the framework structures. Herein we report the synthesis, structures, and characterization of these compounds, [(CH3)4N][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)]·0.5H2O (Me 4 Ubbp), [(CH3CH2)4N]{(UO2)[C6H4(PO3H)(PO3H1.5)]2(H2O)} (Et 4 Ubbp), and [(CH3CH2)2N(CH3)2][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)] (Et 2 Me 2 Ubbp).

elements.content: UO2(NO3)·6H2O (98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries), HF (48 wt %, Aldrich), 1,4-benzenebis(phosphonic) acid (95%, Epsilon Chimie), tetramethylammonium hydroxide (25% ww in methanol, Alfa Aesar), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (20% aq. solution, Alfa Aesar), and diethyldimethylammonium hydroxide (∼20% in water (T), Fluka) were used as received. Reactions were run in PTFE-lined Parr 4749 autoclaves with a 23 mL internal volume. Distilled and Millipore filtered water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ·cm was used in all reactions. The products were thoroughly washed with warm water (to remove unreacted phosphonic acid), then rinsed with methanol, and allowed to dry. Caution! While all the uranium compounds used in these studies contained depleted uranium salts, standard precautions were performed for handling radioactive materials, and all studies were conducted in a laboratory dedicated to studies on actinide elements.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

UO2(NO3)⋅6H2O (98%, International Bio-Analytical Industries), HF (48 wt %, Aldrich), 1,4-benzenebis(phosphonic) acid (95%, Epsilon Chimie), tetramethylammonium hydroxide (25% ww in methanol, Alfa Aesar), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (20% aq. solution, Alfa Aesar), and diethyldimethylammonium hydroxide (~20% in water (T), Fluka) were used as received. Reactions were run in PTFE-lined Parr 4749 autoclaves with a 23 mL internal volume. Distilled and Millipore filtered water with a resistance of 18.2 MΩ⋅cm was used in all reactions. The products were thoroughly washed with warm water (to remove unreacted phosphonic acid), then rinsed with methanol, and allowed to dry.  Caution! While all the uranium compounds used in these studies contained depleted uranium salts, standard precautions were performed for handling radioactive materials, and all studies were conducted in a laboratory dedicated to studies on actinide elements.

elements.content: UO2(NO3)·6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), 0.7 mL of water, and very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave in the presence of either tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.03 mL, 0.29 mmol), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (0.03 mL, 0.21 mmol), or dimethyldiethylammonium hydroxide (0.03 mL, 0.25 mmol) to produce the above compounds, respectively. After being heated for 2−3 days at 200 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 oC/h to 25 oC. The resulting yellow product was washed with warm distilled water and methanol and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. Yellow tablets of the compounds UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed. (Yields are UMe 4 bbp = 61%, UEt 4 bbp = 69%, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp = 71% based on uranium.)

elements.content: Single crystals of UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp were mounted on glass fibers and optically aligned on a Bruker APEXII Quazar CCD X-ray diffractometer using a digital camera. Initial intensity measurements were performed using a IμS X-ray source, a 30 W microfocused sealed tube (MoKα, λ = 0.71073 Å). Standard APEXII software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The intensities of reflections of a sphere were collected by a combination of four sets of exposures (frames). Each set had a different φ angle for the crystal and each exposure covered a range of 0.5° in ω. A total of 1464 frames were collected with an exposure time per frame of 10−30 s, depending on the crystal. SAINT software was used for data integration including Lorentz and polarization corrections. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The program suite SHELXTL was used for space group determination (XPREP), direct methods structure solution (XS), and least-squares refinement (XL). The final refinements included anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. Selected crystallographic information is listed in Table . Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and additional structural information are provided in the (CIFs). Selected bond distances and angles can be found in Tables −.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

Single crystals of UMe  4  bbp, UEt  4  bbp, and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp were mounted on glass fibers and optically aligned on a Bruker APEXII Quazar CCD X-ray diffractometer using a digital camera. Initial intensity measurements were performed using a IμS X-ray source, a 30 W microfocused sealed tube (MoKα, λ = 0.71073 Å). Standard APEXII software was used for determination of the unit cells and data collection control. The intensities of reflections of a sphere were collected by a combination of four sets of exposures (frames). Each set had a different φ angle for the crystal and each exposure covered a range of 0.5° in ω. A total of 1464 frames were collected with an exposure time per frame of 10-30 s, depending on the crystal. SAINT software was used for data integration including Lorentz and polarization corrections. Semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using the program SADABS. The program suite SHELXTL was used for space group determination (XPREP), direct methods structure solution (XS), and least-squares refinement (XL). The final refinements included anisotropic displacement parameters for all atoms. Selected crystallographic information is listed in Table . Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and additional structural information are provided in the  (CIFs). Selected bond distances and angles can be found in Tables  -.

Fluorescence data were acquired from UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp compounds from single crystals using a Craic Technologies UV−vis−NIR microspectrophotometer with a fluorescence attachment. Excitation was achieved using 365 nm light from a mercury lamp for the fluorescence spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectroscopy

Fluorescence data were acquired from UMe  4  bbp, UEt  4  bbp, and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp compounds from single crystals using a Craic Technologies UV-vis-NIR microspectrophotometer with a fluorescence attachment. Excitation was achieved using 365 nm light from a mercury lamp for the fluorescence spectroscopy.

elements.content: The ion-exchange properties of UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp were investigated with the Cs+ ion. A total of 15 mg of finely ground UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp was placed in Teflon vials (8 mL), and 5 mL of a 5 M solution of CsCl was added respectively and the vial was then covered. The solution was mixed for seven days with a mechanical shaker at room temperature and also at 70 °C. The mixture was filtered with filter paper and the solids were air-dried at room temperature. Yellow crystals of UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp suitable for X-ray diffraction were recovered from the vial containing a mixture of crystals and powder. These crystals were mounted on the X-ray diffractometer for structural determination and subsequently for elemental determination using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS).
elements.clean_text:
Ion-Exchange Studies

The ion-exchange properties of UMe  4  bbp, UEt  4  bbp, and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp were investigated with the Cs+ ion. A total of 15 mg of finely ground UMe  4  bbp, UEt  4  bbp, and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp was placed in Teflon vials (8 mL), and 5 mL of a 5 M solution of CsCl was added respectively and the vial was then covered. The solution was mixed for seven days with a mechanical shaker at room temperature and also at 70 °C. The mixture was filtered with filter paper and the solids were air-dried at room temperature. Yellow crystals of UMe  4  bbp, UEt  4  bbp, and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp suitable for X-ray diffraction were recovered from the vial containing a mixture of crystals and powder. These crystals were mounted on the X-ray diffractometer for structural determination and subsequently for elemental determination using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS).

elements.content: [(CH3)4N][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)]·0.5H2O (Me 4 Ubbp), [(CH3CH2)4N]{(UO2)[C6H4(PO3H)(PO3H1.5)]2(H2O)} (Et 4 Ubbp), and [(CH3CH2)2N(CH3)2][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)] (Et 2 Me 2 Ubbp) were synthesized under mild hydrothermal conditions. The addition of hydrofluoric acid to the reaction is essential to reduce the pH and increase the crystallinity of the products. It also serves as ligand in the preparation of UMe4bbp and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

[(CH3)4N][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O (Me  4  Ubbp), [(CH3CH2)4N]{(UO2)[C6H4(PO3H)(PO3H1.5)]2(H2O)} (Et  4  Ubbp), and [(CH3CH2)2N(CH3)2][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)] (Et  2  Me  2  Ubbp) were synthesized under mild hydrothermal conditions. The addition of hydrofluoric acid to the reaction is essential to reduce the pH and increase the crystallinity of the products. It also serves as ligand in the preparation of UMe4bbp and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp.

elements.content: UMe 4 bbp crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/n and has a layered structure consisting of two crystallographically unique uranyl cations, found within UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids that extend in the [bc] plane. These uranyl layers are bridged by the diphosphonate ligand through the PO3 moieties connected by P−O−U and U−F−U bonds into a three-dimensional pillared structure, as shown in Figure a. There are voids in this structure that are filled with (CH3)4N+ cations and occluded water molecules. The view along the a-axis (Figure b) shows the uranyl chains that are connected through the edge-sharing oxygen atoms and corner-sharing fluoride ions.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [(CH3)4N][(UO2)3(O3PC6H4PO3H)2F(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O (Me4Ubbp)

 UMe  4  bbp crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/n and has a layered structure consisting of two crystallographically unique uranyl cations, found within UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids that extend in the [bc] plane. These uranyl layers are bridged by the diphosphonate ligand through the PO3 moieties connected by P-O-U and U-F-U bonds into a three-dimensional pillared structure, as shown in Figure a. There are voids in this structure that are filled with (CH3)4N+ cations and occluded water molecules. The view along the a-axis (Figure b) shows the uranyl chains that are connected through the edge-sharing oxygen atoms and corner-sharing fluoride ions.

elements.content: The UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids are bound by two oxygen atoms along axial positions, and the average UO bond length for U(1), U(2), and U(3) units are 1.768(4) Å, 1.769(4) Å, and 1.775(4) Å. The uranium units are coordinated with oxygen atoms from the phosphonates along equatorial plane, and U−O bond distances range from 2.283(4) Å to 2.498(4) Å. The seven-coordinated U(1) and U(2) also have U−F bond distances of 2.349(3) Å and 2.260(3) Å respectively. A water molecule is coordinated to uranium; the U(1)−O(7) bond distance of 2.494(4) Å is within the normal range of this type of bond. These distances result in a bond-valence sums of 5.95, 5.94, and 6.08 for U(1), U(2), and U(3) respectively; they are consistent with U(VI). The P−O bond distances can be distinguished from the P−OH bond distances based on the bond lengths and whether or not they are coordinating a uranium center. For P(2) and P(3), the longest P−O bond distances of 1.577(4) and 1.580(4) Å, respectively, correspond to a terminal oxygen atom and are therefore sites of protonation.

elements.content: UEt 4 bbp crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pnma and has a layered structure containing seven-coordinate uranium in the form of UO7 pentagonal bipyramids. The aliphatic amine cations create channels along the a-axis as shown in Figure a. Between the anionic layers are disordered (CH3CH2)4N+ cations, so that the overall charge balance is maintained. A view along the [ab] plane (Figure b) shows a crystallographically unique uranyl cation that is connected through four different phosphonates into a one-dimensional chain. A short interaction between the noncoordinating phosphonate oxygen atoms and the water molecule coordinated to the uranium atom exists. These strong hydrogen bonding interactions yield a three-dimensional topology.

Structure of [(CH3CH2)4N]{(UO2)[C6H4(PO3H)(PO3H1.5)]2(H2O)} (Et4Ubbp)

 UEt  4  bbp crystallizes in orthorhombic space group Pnma and has a layered structure containing seven-coordinate uranium in the form of UO7 pentagonal bipyramids. The aliphatic amine cations create channels along the a-axis as shown in Figure a. Between the anionic layers are disordered (CH3CH2)4N+ cations, so that the overall charge balance is maintained. A view along the [ab] plane (Figure b) shows a crystallographically unique uranyl cation that is connected through four different phosphonates into a one-dimensional chain. A short interaction between the noncoordinating phosphonate oxygen atoms and the water molecule coordinated to the uranium atom exists. These strong hydrogen bonding interactions yield a three-dimensional topology.

elements.content: The uranium coordinates with two nearly linear ‘yl’ oxo atoms at the axial positions resulting in a classical uranyl, [OUO]2+ unit, with a bond angle of 178.9(2)° and normal UO bond distances of 1.767(5) and 1.778(6) Å. The equatorial U−O bonds range from 2.312(4) to 2.515(5) Å. We propose that the longest bond distance U(1)−O(9) of 2.515(5) Å belongs to the coordinating water molecule. The bond-valence sum for U(1) is 6.13, which is consistent with U(VI). Three P(1)−O bond distances of 1.496(4), 1.509(3), and 1.576(4) Å and P(2)−O bond distances of 1.494(4), 1.540(4) and 1.563(4) Å reveal the presence of P−OH groups, which are the longest bonds and also correspond to terminal oxygen atoms from the phosphonate group. The intermediate P(2)−O(8) bond distance 1.540(4) Å corresponds to the half-occupied hydrogen atom.

elements.content: UEt 2 Me 2 bbp crystallizes in the centrosymmetric, monoclinic space group P21/m and has two crystallographically unique uranium sites contained within UO6F and UO7 pentagonal bipyramids that are parts of layers. The structure shown in Figure a could be considered as pillared in that the uranyl layers are bridged by the diphosphonate anions. The presence of the (CH3CH2)2(CH3)2N+ cation creates channels in the structure along the a-axis. The view along the [ab] plane (Figure b) reveals pentagonal bipyramids with edge-sharing oxygen atoms to form uranyl dimers that are linked into uranyl chain by the fluoride anions. The two-dimensional sheets of uranyl phosphonate complex consist of phosphonate anions bilayers are cross-linked into three-dimensional framework structure by the fluoride anion. The bound water molecule also forms weak interaction with the bridging phosphonate oxygen atoms that are terminal as well as the nitrogen atom of the diethyldimethylammonium cation.

elements.content: The average uranyl UO bond distances for U(1) and U(2) are 1.775(3) Å and 1.777(4) Å, respectively, while the equatorial U−O bond distances range from 2.345(2) to 2.536(4) Å for U(1), and 2.265(2) to 2.472(2) Å for U(2). The U−F bond distance of 2.2735(2) Å is comparable to other coordinating atoms in the equatorial positions. The longest U−O bond of 2.536(4) Å is assigned to a coordinating water molecule and is within normal ranges for this type of interaction. The bond-valence sums for U(1) and U(2) are 6.05 and 5.96, which are consistent with U(VI). The P(1)−O bond distances of 1.498(3) Å, 1.512(3) Å, and 1.580(3) Å and P(2)−O bond distances of 1.500(3) Å, 1.544(3) Å and 1.551(3) Å consist of a P−OH group, that is not coordinating to the uranium center. The methyl group resides on a mirror plane and is disordered in conjunction with the methylene group of the ethyl chain and disordered 1/3 of the 3-methylene sites.

elements.content: The emission of green light from compounds containing the UO2 2+ moiety when excited with UV light can be identified from a series of strongly vibronically coupled charge-transfer features centered near 520 nm. This phenomenon has been known for decades and typically consists of a five-peak spectrum, although far more lines can be observed at low temperature. Various factors such as crystallinity of the sample, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, etc. are responsible for the decrease in resolution of individual transitions. Denning and co-workers have examined in detail these transitions for the solid samples containing the (UO2Cl4)2− anion owing to its crystallization in a cubic space group. However, not all uranyl compounds fluoresce and the mechanisms of the emission from uranyl containing compounds are complex. Grohol and Clearfield demonstrated a considerable variance in the luminescence properties of two closely related uranyl phenylphosphonate compounds, [UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)]2·8H2O and UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)·2H2O, whose structural differences are based on the conformational differences of the phosphonate anions. As shown in Figure , all these newly synthesized organically templated uranyl diphosphonate compounds are luminescent and show the classical fluorescence spectra of uranyl compounds with five clearly resolved vibronic transitions centered near 540 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Spectroscopy

The emission of green light from compounds containing the UO2 2+ moiety when excited with UV light can be identified from a series of strongly vibronically coupled charge-transfer features centered near 520 nm. This phenomenon has been known for decades and typically consists of a five-peak spectrum, although far more lines can be observed at low temperature. Various factors such as crystallinity of the sample, disorder within the equatorial plane of the uranyl group, etc. are responsible for the decrease in resolution of individual transitions. Denning and co-workers have examined in detail these transitions for the solid samples containing the (UO2Cl4)2- anion owing to its crystallization in a cubic space group. However, not all uranyl compounds fluoresce and the mechanisms of the emission from uranyl containing compounds are complex. Grohol and Clearfield demonstrated a considerable variance in the luminescence properties of two closely related uranyl phenylphosphonate compounds, [UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)]2⋅8H2O and UO2(HO3PC6H5)2(H2O)⋅2H2O, whose structural differences are based on the conformational differences of the phosphonate anions. As shown in Figure , all these newly synthesized organically templated uranyl diphosphonate compounds are luminescent and show the classical fluorescence spectra of uranyl compounds with five clearly resolved vibronic transitions centered near 540 nm.

elements.content: The use of framework uranium materials as promising hosts for the long-term storage of radionuclides found in used nuclear fuel is interesting and would be a potential peaceful application of depleted uranium. The negatively charged uranyl framework and charge balancing aliphatic amine cations that create channels in these materials suggests that these voids may serve as a good host materials for cationic ion-exchange applications. We usually screen all the templated uranium phosphonates frameworks that we have synthesized in our laboratory for their potential as ion-exchange materials. We therefore investigated the ion-exchange properties of these materials and our experiments revealed that complete exchange of the aliphatic amine cations for Cs+ was difficult. The finely ground crystals of the framework materials remained intact during the ion-exchange experiments. When one takes a closer look at the topology of these structures, 1a, 2a, and 3a, one can notice that the channel openings are too small as a result of the strong steric hindrances from the phenyl ring and the aliphatic amine cations. The bulky (CH3)4N+, (CH3CH2)4N+, and (CH3CH2)2(CH3)2N+ cations are tightly locked and/or packed in place within the voids unlike the organically templated uranium phosphate fluoride material, [(CH3)2NH(CH2)2NH(CH3)2][(UO2)2F2(HPO4)2], where the cationic amines separate the anionic uranyl phosphate fluoride layers, the templates in this material were exchanged for alkali with rearrangement and transformation of the structural topology.
elements.clean_text:
Ion-Exchange Reactions

The use of framework uranium materials as promising hosts for the long-term storage of radionuclides found in used nuclear fuel is interesting and would be a potential peaceful application of depleted uranium. The negatively charged uranyl framework and charge balancing aliphatic amine cations that create channels in these materials suggests that these voids may serve as a good host materials for cationic ion-exchange applications. We usually screen all the templated uranium phosphonates frameworks that we have synthesized in our laboratory for their potential as ion-exchange materials. We therefore investigated the ion-exchange properties of these materials and our experiments revealed that complete exchange of the aliphatic amine cations for Cs+ was difficult. The finely ground crystals of the framework materials remained intact during the ion-exchange experiments. When one takes a closer look at the topology of these structures, 1a, 2a, and 3a, one can notice that the channel openings are too small as a result of the strong steric hindrances from the phenyl ring and the aliphatic amine cations. The bulky (CH3)4N+, (CH3CH2)4N+, and (CH3CH2)2(CH3)2N+ cations are tightly locked and/or packed in place within the voids unlike the organically templated uranium phosphate fluoride material, [(CH3)2NH(CH2)2NH(CH3)2][(UO2)2F2(HPO4)2], where the cationic amines separate the anionic uranyl phosphate fluoride layers, the templates in this material were exchanged for alkali with rearrangement and transformation of the structural topology.

elements.content: The results we reported here and in our previous communication on the synthesis of luminescent pillared uranyl materials demonstrate that the construction of pillared and three-dimensional framework structures can be accomplished through the ultility of template-mediated hydrothermal synthesis along with rigid phenyl spacers for the synthesis of a variety of struture types in which the templates and fluoride are incorporated into the inorganic framework. Unlike our previous compound, [C12H10N2]{(UO2)3[C6H4(PO3)2]2}·H2O, which was constructed from a combination of UO7 pentagonal bipyramids and UO6 tetragonal bipyramids, these new materials contain seven-coordinate uranium centers within UO6F or UO7 dimers. We are finally reaching the point that we can generalize on the ion-exchange capability of the materials we prepare with organic templates. Although the topology seems promising for this purpose, we can infer from our work that the use of alkali or alkali earth metals as templating agents will be more fruitful. Organic templates are seemingly locked in pocket-like voids and are held in place by strong steric effects from the bulky phenyl spacers and the templates. These compounds also demonstrate high stability under the ion-exchange conditions. They are highly networked and dense, and thus the coordination environment and structural topologies are playing a major role here.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The results we reported here and in our previous communication on the synthesis of luminescent pillared uranyl materials demonstrate that the construction of pillared and three-dimensional framework structures can be accomplished through the ultility of template-mediated hydrothermal synthesis along with rigid phenyl spacers for the synthesis of a variety of struture types in which the templates and fluoride are incorporated into the inorganic framework. Unlike our previous compound, [C12H10N2]{(UO2)3[C6H4(PO3)2]2}⋅H2O, which was constructed from a combination of UO7 pentagonal bipyramids and UO6 tetragonal bipyramids, these new materials contain seven-coordinate uranium centers within UO6F or UO7 dimers. We are finally reaching the point that we can generalize on the ion-exchange capability of the materials we prepare with organic templates. Although the topology seems promising for this purpose, we can infer from our work that the use of alkali or alkali earth metals as templating agents will be more fruitful. Organic templates are seemingly locked in pocket-like voids and are held in place by strong steric effects from the bulky phenyl spacers and the templates. These compounds also demonstrate high stability under the ion-exchange conditions. They are highly networked and dense, and thus the coordination environment and structural topologies are playing a major role here.

elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content: UO2(NO3)·6H2O (50.2 mg, 0.1 mmol), 1,4-benzenebisphosphonic acid (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol), 0.7 mL of water, and very small quantities of HF were loaded into a 23 mL autoclave in the presence of either tetramethylammonium hydroxide (0.03 mL, 0.29 mmol), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (0.03 mL, 0.21 mmol), or dimethyldiethylammonium hydroxide (0.03 mL, 0.25 mmol) to produce the above compounds, respectively. After being heated for 2−3 days at 200 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 oC/h to 25 oC. The resulting yellow product was washed with warm distilled water and methanol and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. Yellow tablets of the compounds UMe 4 bbp, UEt 4 bbp, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed. (Yields are UMe 4 bbp = 61%, UEt 4 bbp = 69%, and UEt 2 Me 2 bbp = 71% based on uranium.)

After being heated for 2-3 days at 200 °C, the autoclave was then cooled at an average rate of 5 oC/h to 25 oC. The resulting yellow product was washed with warm distilled water and methanol and allowed to air-dry at room temperature. Yellow tablets of the compounds UMe  4  bbp, UEt  4  bbp, and UEt  2  Me  2  bbp suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were formed.
